channel.title: Science News - Times of India
channel.description: Latest news, top updates and current developments from the world of Health, Science and technology along with tips on physical & mental health and fitness.

item.title: Pill to cure ‘couch potatoes’ ?
item.description: A gene mutation may explain why some people are more likely than others to be couch potatoes , according to a study which offers hope of a personalized pill to counter the problem.

item.title: This app uses your phone for R&D while you sleep
item.description: A new app that allows you to ‘donate’ the processing power of your mobile phone for scientific research while you sleep has been developed.

item.title: World genetic map finds Genghis Khan’s impact across Asia
item.description: The world’s most exhaustive map has been made detailing genetic histories of 95 different populations across the world revealing genetic impact of European colonialism, Arab slave trade, Genghis Khan’s empire and European traders near the Silk Road mixing with people in China.

item.title: Now, geographical passwords
item.description: A scientist has devised “geographical passwords” that con provide secure access to different entities and at the same time reduce many of the vulnerabilities associated with current password-based schemes.

item.title: Nazis may have tried to use mosquitoes as weapons, research says
item.description: Vectorborne diseases like malaria and dengue continue to be global killers. And it is this deadly effect of mosquitoes that impressed the Nazis.

item.title: Scientists 'grow' human lungs in lab for first time
item.description: For the first time, US scientists have grown human lungs in a lab, an advance in regenerative medicine that aims to address the problem of organ donor shortage.

item.title: Russian satellite Kosmos-1220 to crash to Earth today with ‘very real danger’ to populated areas
item.description: A Russian satellite is expected to re-enter the Earth’s atmosphere today, reportedly representing a "very real danger" to densely populated areas.

item.title: Nuclear bombs can destroy killer asteroids in space
item.description: Asteroids that pose a threat to Earth can be destroyed in space using a nuclear bomb, even with warning times of a week or less, scientists say.

item.title: International Space Station braces for its coldest spot
item.description: Nasa scientist are on the job to create the coldest spot aboard the International Space Station (ISS) that would help them unravel the secrets behind interesting and novel quantum phenomena.

item.title: New Nasa rover camera may advance search for alien life
item.description: Fink and his team tested their Astrobiological Imager in the Mojave Desert, using it to photograph sandstone outcroppings and scan them for promising patches indicating microbe colonies on the rocks.

item.title: ‘Honey heals wounds faster than betadine’
item.description: Dr Pillai uses a locally-manufactured ventriculo-peritoneal (VP) shunt to drain out fluid from the brain. “Traditional shunts made abroad are 10 times costlier — the ones we use cost Rs 3,000 per unit,” says Pillai.

item.title: Key to long marriage? adultery
item.description: 'Outsourcing' sex could be beneficial as couples expect more from each other than ever before

item.title: How stem cells decide liver, pancreas formation
item.description: How do stem cells decide whether to become liver cells or pancreatic cells during development?

item.title: Adultery may be the key to a long, happy marriage, psychologists claim
item.description: Allowing your partner to sleep with other people could be the key to a happy marriage, psychologists have claimed.

item.title: Breast milk contains natural stress hormone
item.description: A hormone that is released when someone is under physical or emotional stress has been found in breast milk and appears to affect babies differently depending on their sex, a study of laboratory monkeys has shown.

item.title: Solitary confinement ravages the mind, but its use widespread
item.description: Many of the more than 80,000 prisoners currently held in solitary confinement in US prisons — and countless more around the world — are not as fortunate.

item.title: New forms of 'racism' rise in science research
item.description: New forms of discrimination, known as neoracism, are taking hold in scientific research, spreading the belief that races exist and are different in terms of biology, behaviour and culture.

item.title: China's second lunar probe travels 70 million km
item.description: China's second lunar probe, Chang'e-2, has traveled more than 70 million km into deep space in good condition, so far the longest voyage of any Chinese spacecraft, a senior engineer said Friday.

item.title: Early Britons chose dairy food over fish
item.description: Archaeologists and chemists tracing ancient British diets have found that more than 99% of the earliest farmer's cooking pots lacked seafood residues.

item.title: Now, practise kissing with this pillow
item.description: In a bizarre invention, a Florida designer has developed a pillow with a 'mouth' that can help people perfect their kissing technique.

item.title: Termite-bots to build towers
item.description: An Indian-origin scientist at Harvard has developed an army of autonomous termitelike robots that can build complex structures such as towers and pyramids without any supervision.

item.title: Study: Male homosexuality partly influenced by genes
item.description: An American study has found new evidence that male homosexuality is influenced by genes - but environmental and social factors also play a role.

item.title: Being lazy could be genetic, scientists say
item.description: A mutation in a gene with a critical role in the brain could explain why some people are "couch potatoes" according to researchers.

item.title: Tracing ancestry, researchers produce a genetic atlas of human mixing events
item.description: The rise and fall of empires, the march of armies, the flow of trade routes, the practice of slavery — all these events have led to a mixing of populations around the world. Such episodes have left a record in the human genome, but one that has so far been too complex to decipher on a global scale.

item.title: What is the recipe for a great marriage? Psychologists say they have the answer
item.description: A marriage is supposed to be made in heaven but if it is to work in the 21st Century it has to allow both partners to discover their inner potential rather than being merely an institution for living together and raising children, a study has found.
